<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Good morning. </strong>Know what washes down a Saturday morning Brew better than anything? A Sunday morning Brew, chock full of premium, exclusive content. It's called Light Roast, and it's yours for just three referrals. Rumor has it this week's Light Roast has been called "lit" on two separate occasions.</p>

<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
TELECOM
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2019/07/27/t-mobile-sprint-get-doj-approval-26-billion-merger?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
T-Mobile and Sprint Take the Next Step
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">How do you know when it’s official? When the Justice Department gives its blessing. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">T-Mobile (+5.43%) and Sprint (+7.39%) finally <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2019/07/26/t-mobile-sprint-merger-approved-by-doj.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">got that validation</a> yesterday when DOJ officials greenlighted their more than $26 billion merger after five years of on-again, off-again (the merger was first proposed in June 2014).</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Sprint’s taking T-Mobile’s name: </strong><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/07/26/business/media/sprint-tmobile-merger.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Once combined</a>, the country’s third and fourth largest wireless providers plan to be called T-Mobile and serve over 90 million U.S. customers. The first and second largest providers, Verizon and AT&T, each have about 100 million wireless customers.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">But relationships take work</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">And attorneys general from 13 states and D.C. are testing this pair’s devotion. They <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2019/6/11/18661501/t-mobile-sprint-merger-state-attorney-general-lawsuit-block?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">sued to block</a> the merger last month, arguing that reducing the number of big-league telecom players limits competition and raises prices. If the marriage survives the lawsuit, <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/justice-department-approves-merger-of-t-mobile-us-and-sprint-11564155026?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">95% of American cellphone customers</a> will get service from the top three U.S. operators.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The trial is scheduled to start in October...and T-Mobile said it expects to close the Sprint deal in the second half of the year.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">The DOJ knows it’s all about compromise </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Which is where Dish Network (+0.87%) and its sought-after airwaves come in. Under the deal officials struck with T-Mobile and Sprint, satellite TV provider Dish will snap up some of the pair’s divestitures and promise the DOJ a 5G rollout.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Dish will get about 9 million Sprint prepaid cellphone customers, which it can move from pay-as-you-go to the more profitable postpaid model. It’ll also be writing thank you notes for more wireless spectrum, hundreds of retail locations, and "robust access" to the newly combined company’s network.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>The shadow hanging over all of this is that coveted 5G tech. The government wants the U.S. to get to the next wireless generation ASAP, which is why <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-07-26/t-mobile-wins-u-s-nod-for-sprint-deal-with-plan-to-create-rival?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">part of the deal involves</a> T-Mobile promising 5G access for 97% of the U.S. population in three years.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-top: 12px;">
<a href="https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2019%2F07%2F27%2Ft-mobile-sprint-get-doj-approval-26-billion-merger" target="_blank" rel="noopener" style="text-decoration: none;" class="">
<img alt="" style="display: inline-block; width: 25px" width="25" src="https://media.sailthru.com/5z8/1k4/4/2/5e865734bf6f7.jpg">
</a><span>  </span>
<a href="https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=Once+combined%2C+the+country%E2%80%99s+third+and+fourth+largest+wireless+providers+plan+to+be+called+T-Mobile+and+serve+over+90+million+U.S.+customers&url=https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2019/07/27/t-mobile-sprint-get-doj-approval-26-billion-merger&via=MorningBrew" target="_blank" rel="noopener" style="text-decoration: none;" class="">

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ECONOMY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2019/07/27/commerce-department-updates-gdp-stats?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
You Can’t Always Get What You Want
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Updated stats from the Commerce Department showed <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-07-26/trump-s-3-growth-feat-in-2018-undone-by-annual-data-revisions?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">GDP expanded</a> 2.5% on a Q4-over-Q4 basis in 2018. We’ll take it, but...</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The previous estimate was 3%.</strong> Achieving that would have been cause for popping the Martinelli’s at the White House, <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2019/07/26/gdp-growth-fails-to-hit-trumps-3percent-target-in-2018.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">which hoped</a> for 3% growth in 2018 c/o tax cuts, trade policy, and regulatory rollbacks. FYI, GDP gains in the first two years of the Trump administration <em>did</em> top this economic expansion’s average 2.3% yearly growth rate.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bringing it back to this year: </strong>In Q2, the economy grew at a 2.1% annualized pace. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The good: That was above the median forecast.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The bad: It followed a 3.1% growth reading in the previous quarter. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The ugly: Compared to Q2 of last year, GDP grew 2.3%...the slowest in two years.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Still, the economy’s decade-long expansion <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/07/26/business/economy/us-gdp-growth.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">remains</a> on solid footing. Last quarter, strong consumer spending <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/u-s-economy-grew-at-2-1-rate-in-second-quarter-11564144334?mod=hp_lead_pos3&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">balanced out</a> the first decline in business investment since 2016.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead:</strong> These GDP stats are the kindling the Fed needs to keep the rate-cut fires burning.</p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ENERGY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2019/07/27/apple-amazon-top-list-u-s-solar-energy-use?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
It’s Always Sunny in Cupertino
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">First, Apple became the No. 1 <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/stories/apple-declares-independence/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">buyer of chip manufacturers</a>. Now, it’s ranked first in the Solar Energy Industries Association (SEIA) <a href="http://www.solarmeansbusiness.com/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">report</a> on U.S. companies’ 2018 solar energy procurement. Big week.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Last year, Apple (+0.35%) tallied 393.3 megawatts (MW) of installed solar capacity—a fair prize for spending a decade investing in solar.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture: </strong>In the tech world, solar panels have the kind of install rate young engineers dream of. Amazon <a href="https://techcrunch.com/2019/07/25/apple-leads-corporate-american-solar-energy-installers/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">came in second</a> at 329.8 MW, and Google landed at sixth with 142.9 MW. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">*Urkel voice* But there’s an important distinction for the 2018 report. </strong>The SEIA <a href="https://venturebeat.com/2019/07/25/apple-and-amazon-become-top-u-s-solar-users-besting-target-and-walmart/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">changed the way</a> it measures procurement, this time including off-site installations in its calculations. Had the SEIA only counted on-site installations, Target and Walmart <a href="https://www.axios.com/solar-power-corporate-apple-amazon-renewable-energy-37536035-4f5f-4ddf-b8c1-a62ecc2e744b.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">would’ve led the pack</a>, as they have in years past.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out:</strong> Individual companies are quickly pursuing renewable energy (especially solar) as it becomes more affordable. But scientists say <em>the entire economy</em> <a href="https://www.nature.com/articles/s41558-018-0198-6?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">needs complete decarbonization</a> in the next decade to avoid the worst fallout from climate change.</p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
CRYPTO
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2019/07/27/irs-sending-warnings-10-000-cryptocurrency-holders?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
IRS Cracks the Crypto Whip
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Confusing: Doing your taxes.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Confusinger: Understanding cryptocurrencies.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Confusingest: Doing your taxes when you own cryptocurrencies.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The Internal Revenue Service is sympathetic, but Uncle Sam waits for no one. IRS officials have <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/irs-sending-warning-letters-to-more-than-10-000-cryptocurrency-holders-11564159523?mod=hp_lead_pos1&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">begun sending</a> letters to 10,000+ cryptocurrency holders <a href="https://thehill.com/blogs/blog-briefing-room/news/454925-irs-to-send-warning-letter-to-over-10k-cryptocurrency-holders?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">warning them</a> that they might be subject to penalties for failing to report income and pay taxes on crypto transactions.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The more you know: </strong>Virtual currencies were classified as an investment property for federal tax purposes in 2014. That means they’re treated like stocks or real estate—when sold at a profit, they trigger tax consequences.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Ever since Satoshi hit send on the bitcoin white paper, IRS officials have been pounding the Advil. They’ve struggled to enforce laws on digital assets like bitcoin, especially as their popularity skyrockets. These letters are one of the IRS’s <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-07-26/the-irs-is-tracking-down-10-000-crypto-owners-to-pay-back-taxes?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">biggest endeavors</a> yet to stymie crypto-related tax avoidance.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">+ While we’re here: </strong>Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said this week that U.S. regulators plan to issue new crypto regulations soon to keep the asset class from harming the financial system.</p>

When the Justice Department gives its blessing. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eT-Mobile (+5.43%) and Sprint (+7.39%) finally \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2019/07/26/t-mobile-sprint-merger-approved-by-doj.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003egot that validation\u003c/a\u003e yesterday when DOJ officials greenlighted their more than $26 billion merger after five years of on-again, off-again (the merger was first proposed in June 2014).\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eSprint’s taking T-Mobile’s name: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2019/07/26/business/media/sprint-tmobile-merger.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eOnce combined\u003c/a\u003e, the country’s third and fourth largest wireless providers plan to be called T-Mobile and serve over 90 million U.S. customers. The first and second largest providers, Verizon and AT\u0026T, each have about 100 million wireless customers.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eBut relationships take work\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAnd attorneys general from 13 states and D.C. are testing this pair’s devotion. They \u003ca href=\"https://www.theverge.com/2019/6/11/18661501/t-mobile-sprint-merger-state-attorney-general-lawsuit-block?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esued to block\u003c/a\u003e the merger last month, arguing that reducing the number of big-league telecom players limits competition and raises prices. If the marriage survives the lawsuit, \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/justice-department-approves-merger-of-t-mobile-us-and-sprint-11564155026?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e95% of American cellphone customers\u003c/a\u003e will get service from the top three U.S. operators.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe trial is scheduled to start in October...and T-Mobile said it expects to close the Sprint deal in the second half of the year.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThe DOJ knows it’s all about compromise \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWhich is where Dish Network (+0.87%) and its sought-after airwaves come in. Under the deal officials struck with T-Mobile and Sprint, satellite TV provider Dish will snap up some of the pair’s divestitures and promise the DOJ a 5G rollout.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eDish will get about 9 million Sprint prepaid cellphone customers, which it can move from pay-as-you-go to the more profitable postpaid model. It’ll also be writing thank you notes for more wireless spectrum, hundreds of retail locations, and \"robust access\" to the newly combined company’s network.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eThe shadow hanging over all of this is that coveted 5G tech. The government wants the U.S. to get to the next wireless generation ASAP, which is why \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-07-26/t-mobile-wins-u-s-nod-for-sprint-deal-with-plan-to-create-rival?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003epart of the deal involves\u003c/a\u003e T-Mobile promising 5G access for 97% of the U.S. population in three style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nYou Can’t Always Get What You Want\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eUpdated stats from the Commerce Department showed \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-07-26/trump-s-3-growth-feat-in-2018-undone-by-annual-data-revisions?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eGDP expanded\u003c/a\u003e 2.5% on a Q4-over-Q4 basis in 2018. We’ll take it, but...\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe previous estimate was 3%.\u003c/strong\u003e Achieving that would have been cause for popping the Martinelli’s at the White House, \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2019/07/26/gdp-growth-fails-to-hit-trumps-3percent-target-in-2018.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewhich hoped\u003c/a\u003e for 3% growth in 2018 c/o tax cuts, trade policy, and regulatory rollbacks. FYI, GDP gains in the first two years of the Trump administration \u003cem\u003edid\u003c/em\u003e top this economic expansion’s average 2.3% yearly growth rate.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBringing it back to this year: \u003c/strong\u003eIn Q2, the economy grew at a 2.1% annualized pace. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe good: That was above the median forecast.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe bad: It followed a 3.1% growth reading in the previous quarter. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe ugly: Compared to Q2 of last year, GDP grew 2.3%...the slowest in two years.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eStill, the economy’s decade-long expansion \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2019/07/26/business/economy/us-gdp-growth.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eremains\u003c/a\u003e on solid footing. Last quarter, strong consumer spending \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/u-s-economy-grew-at-2-1-rate-in-second-quarter-11564144334?mod=hp_lead_pos3\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ebalanced out\u003c/a\u003e the first decline in business investment since 2016.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead:\u003c/strong\u003e These GDP stats are the style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFirst, Apple became the No. 1 \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/stories/apple-declares-independence/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ebuyer of chip manufacturers\u003c/a\u003e. Now, it’s ranked first in the Solar Energy Industries Association (SEIA) \u003ca href=\"http://www.solarmeansbusiness.com/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ereport\u003c/a\u003e on U.S. companies’ 2018 solar energy procurement. Big week.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eLast year, Apple (+0.35%) tallied 393.3 megawatts (MW) of installed solar capacity—a fair prize for spending a decade investing in solar.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture: \u003c/strong\u003eIn the tech world, solar panels have the kind of install rate young engineers dream of. Amazon \u003ca href=\"https://techcrunch.com/2019/07/25/apple-leads-corporate-american-solar-energy-installers/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecame in second\u003c/a\u003e at 329.8 MW, and Google landed at sixth with 142.9 MW. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e*Urkel voice* But there’s an important distinction for the 2018 report. \u003c/strong\u003eThe SEIA \u003ca href=\"https://venturebeat.com/2019/07/25/apple-and-amazon-become-top-u-s-solar-users-besting-target-and-walmart/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003echanged the way\u003c/a\u003e it measures procurement, this time including off-site installations in its calculations. Had the SEIA only counted on-site installations, Target and Walmart \u003ca href=\"https://www.axios.com/solar-power-corporate-apple-amazon-renewable-energy-37536035-4f5f-4ddf-b8c1-a62ecc2e744b.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewould’ve led the pack\u003c/a\u003e, as they have in years past.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out:\u003c/strong\u003e Individual companies are quickly pursuing renewable energy (especially solar) as it becomes more affordable. But scientists say \u003cem\u003ethe entire economy\u003c/em\u003e \u003ca href=\"https://www.nature.com/articles/s41558-018-0198-6?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eneeds complete decarbonization\u003c/a\u003e in the next decade to avoid the worst fallout from climate
